question: [File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: actuate()] [Race Condition] Between valid_attestation_count check at line 120 and enable_oracle at line 123, can another transaction modify the oracle state, causing oracles to be enabled with incorrect attestation counts? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: actuate()] [Attestation Validity Window] The add_attestation call at line 109 uses clock.timestamp_ms() - if attestations have their own validity windows, can old attestations still count toward the min_attestations threshold at line 121? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: actuate()] [Oracle Validity Overflow] At line 122, expiration_time_ms is calculated as clock.timestamp_ms() + queue.oracle_validity_length_ms() - can this addition overflow for large validity lengths, creating oracles that expire in the distant past? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: actuate()] [Enable Oracle DoS] If enable_oracle at line 123 can be called multiple times for the same secp256k1_key, can attackers repeatedly enable oracles to consume gas or corrupt oracle state? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: actuate()] [Key Reuse] Can the same secp256k1_key be used across multiple oracles, and if so, does line 120's valid_attestation_count aggregate across all oracles, potentially enabling unintended oracles? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: run()] [Reentrancy] The run() function at lines 135-164 calls validate then actuate without state modifications in between - can reentrancy between these calls allow state manipulation if other modules modify oracle/queue/guardian objects? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: run()] [TOCTOU] Time-of-check-time-of-use vulnerability between validate() checks (lines 145-154) and actuate() actions (lines 155-163) - can oracle state change between validation and actuation, bypassing security checks? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: actuate()] [State Modification Order] Attestation is added at line 109 before checking if oracle should be enabled at line 121 - can partial state modifications create inconsistent oracle states if transaction fails after add_attestation? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Read-Only Queue] The queue parameter is passed as immutable reference at line 45 - can its internal state be modified by other transactions during validation, causing TOCTOU issues with min_attestations or guardian_queue_id? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: actuate()] [Event Emission Timing] Events are emitted at lines 118, 131 after state changes - if transaction reverts after event emission, can off-chain systems be deceived by emitted but uncommitted events? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: validate()] [MrEnclave Bypass] The mr_enclave parameter at line 48 is included in attestation message hash at line 81 but not validated against any whitelist - can attackers provide arbitrary mr_enclave values to create valid attestations for malicious enclaves? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Hardcoded Zero Bytes] Line 82 includes hardcoded zero bytes in attestation message - what is the purpose of this field, and can manipulating the interpretation of these bytes create signature collisions? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: actuate()] [MrEnclave Storage] The mr_enclave is passed to enable_oracle at line 123 but not validated - can malicious enclaves be permanently associated with oracle objects, compromising data integrity? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: run()] [MrEnclave Consistency] The mr_enclave is used in both validate (line 150) and actuate (line 161) - can different mr_enclave values be passed to these functions through a malicious wrapper, causing validation/actuation mismatch? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Key Extraction] Lines 76-77 extract oracle_key and queue_key from oracle object - can these keys be manipulated in the Oracle struct to bypass signature verification by creating colliding attestation messages? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Secp256k1 Key Format] The secp256k1_key parameter at line 49 is passed without format validation before being used in attestation message at line 83 - can malformed keys cause unexpected behavior in hash generation? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: actuate()] [Key Storage] The secp256k1_key is stored in attestation at line 106 and used for counting at line 120 - can key collision attacks allow one key to accumulate attestations intended for different oracles? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: actuate()] [Key Lifecycle] When enable_oracle is called at line 123 with secp256k1_key, is there validation that this key hasn't been used for other oracles, preventing key reuse across different oracle contexts? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: run()] [Public Entry Point] The run() function at line 135 is marked as 'public entry', allowing any caller to submit attestations - can malicious actors spam attestations to DoS the system or corrupt oracle state? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: validate()] [No Caller Validation] Neither validate() nor actuate() check the transaction sender - can unauthorized parties with valid signatures from compromised guardians enable oracles without proper authorization? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: actuate()] [Oracle Mutation] The oracle parameter at line 96 is mutable reference - who has permission to pass this reference, and can unauthorized callers gain mutable access to oracle objects through this function? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: run()] [Guardian Ownership] No check verifies that the caller owns or is authorized to use the guardian oracle object at line 138 - can attackers use other users' guardian objects to create attestations? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: actuate()] [Event Sequence] AttestationCreated is emitted at line 118 for every attestation, but AttestationResolved at line 131 only when threshold is reached - can monitoring systems be confused by asymmetric event patterns? (Low)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: actuate()] [Event Data Integrity] The AttestationCreated event at lines 112-117 includes oracle_id, guardian_id, and secp256k1_key - can discrepancies between event data and actual oracle state lead to off-chain system corruption? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: actuate()] [Event Timestamp] Events use clock.timestamp_ms() at lines 116, 129 while attestation uses timestamp_seconds * 1000 at line 107 - can timestamp discrepancies between attestation data and event data confuse monitoring systems?
